message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication that most effectively increases serum HDL levels is niacin (nicotinic acid). A common side effect of niacin is flushing, which is often harmless but may cause discomfort. The other options are less commonly associated with niacin use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HDL levels are often referred to as “good cholesterol” and it is desirable to have higher levels of HDL in the blood. Niacin is a lipid level modifying drug that most effectively increases serum HDL levels but can cause flushing as a side effect. Gallstones and hepatotoxicity are potential side effects of statins, which primarily work to lower LDL levels. Myalgia can also be a side effect of statins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication used to increase serum HDL levels is niacin, and flushing is a common side effect. Gallstones, hepatotoxicity, and myalgia are less common side effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Drugs that increase HDL levels often cause flushing as a side effect. Gallstones are a potential side effect of drugs that decrease LDL levels. Hepatotoxicity and myalgia are potential side effects of various lipid-modifying drugs, but not specifically those that increase HDL levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication that most effectively increases serum HDL levels is niacin, which is known to cause flushing as a common side effect. Gallstones, hepatotoxicity, and myalgia are not commonly associated with niacin use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication that most effectively increases serum HDL levels is Niacin. Flushing is a common side effect of Niacin and patients should be informed about this prior to starting treatment. Gallstones, hepatotoxicity, and myalgia are not commonly associated with Niacin therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication that most effectively increases HDL levels is niacin, and one of its most common side effects is flushing. Gallstones, hepatotoxicity, and myalgia are not typically associated with niacin use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that most effectively increases serum HDL levels is niacin. One of the most common side effects associated with niacin is flushing. Gallstones and hepatotoxicity are not associated with niacin. Myalgia is a potential side effect of statins, which are used to lower LDL levels.
